an9.13:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an9.13:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an9.13:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an9.13:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Sāriputta:

an9.13:1.3.pli: “kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ samparāyavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:1.3.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced in this life be experienced by me in lives to come’?”

an9.13:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ samparāyavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:2.1.eng: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced in lives to come be experienced by me in this life’?”

an9.13:3.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ dukkhavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:3.1.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced as pleasant be experienced by me as painful’?”

an9.13:4.1.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso, sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ dukkhavedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:4.1.eng: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced as painful be experienced by me as pleasant’?”

an9.13:5.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ paripakkavedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ aparipakkavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:5.1.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced when ripe be experienced by me when unripe’?”

an9.13:6.1.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ aparipakkavedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ paripakkavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:6.1.eng: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced when unripe be experienced by me when ripe’?”

an9.13:7.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ bahuvedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ appavedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:7.1.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced a lot be experienced by me a little’?”

an9.13:8.1.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ appavedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ bahuvedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:8.1.eng: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced a little be experienced by me a lot’?”

an9.13:9.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ vedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ avedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:9.1.eng: “Is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds to be experienced by me be not experienced’?”

an9.13:10.1.pli: “Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, ‘yaṃ kammaṃ avedanīyaṃ, taṃ me kammaṃ vedanīyaṃ hotū’ti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:10.1.eng: “Then is the spiritual life lived under the Buddha for this purpose: ‘May deeds not to be experienced be experienced’?”

an9.13:11.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ samparāyavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:11.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, when you were asked whether the spiritual life was lived under the Buddha so that deeds to be experienced in this life are experienced in lives to come, you said, ‘Certainly not’.

an9.13:12.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ samparāyavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ diṭṭhadhammavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:12.1.eng: When you were asked whether the spiritual life was lived under the Buddha so that deeds to be experienced in lives to come are experienced in this life …

an9.13:13.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ dukkhavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:13.1.eng: deeds to be experienced as pleasant are experienced as painful …

an9.13:14.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ dukkhavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ sukhavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:14.1.eng: deeds to be experienced as painful are experienced as pleasant …

an9.13:15.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ paripakkavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ aparipakkavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:15.1.eng: deeds to be experienced when ripe are experienced when unripe …

an9.13:16.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ aparipakkavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ paripakkavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:16.1.eng: deeds to be experienced when unripe are experienced when ripe …

an9.13:17.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ bahuvedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ appavedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:17.1.eng: deeds to be experienced a lot are experienced a little …

an9.13:18.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ appavedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ bahuvedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:18.1.eng: deeds to be experienced a little are experienced a lot …

an9.13:19.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ vedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ avedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:19.1.eng: deeds to be experienced are not experienced …

an9.13:20.1.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, yaṃ kammaṃ avedanīyaṃ taṃ me kammaṃ vedanīyaṃ hotūti, etassa atthāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘no hidaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an9.13:20.1.eng: When you were asked whether the spiritual life was lived under the Buddha so that deeds not to be experienced are experienced, you said, ‘Certainly not.’

an9.13:20.2.pli: Atha kimatthaṃ carahāvuso, bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti?
an9.13:20.2.eng: Then what exactly is the purpose of leading the spiritual life under the Buddha?”

an9.13:21.1.pli: “Yaṃ khvassa, āvuso, aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ appattaṃ asacchikataṃ anabhisametaṃ, tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya pattiyā sacchikiriyāya abhisamayāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatīti.
an9.13:21.1.eng: “Reverend, the spiritual life is lived under the Buddha to know, see, attain, realize, and comprehend that which is unknown, unseen, unattained, unrealized, and uncomprehended.”

an9.13:21.2.pli: Kiṃ panassāvuso, aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ appattaṃ asacchikataṃ anabhisametaṃ, yassa ñāṇāya dassanāya pattiyā sacchikiriyāya abhisamayāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatīti?
an9.13:21.2.eng: “But what is the unknown, unseen, unattained, unrealized, and uncomprehended?”

an9.13:21.3.pli: ‘Idaṃ dukkhan’ti khvassa, āvuso, aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ appattaṃ asacchikataṃ anabhisametaṃ.

an9.13:21.4.pli: Tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya pattiyā sacchikiriyāya abhisamayāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati.

an9.13:21.5.pli: ‘Ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti khvassa, āvuso …pe… ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti khvassa, āvuso …pe…
an9.13:21.5.eng: ‘This is the origin of suffering.’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering.’ …

an9.13:21.6.pli: ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti khvassa, āvuso, aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ appattaṃ asacchikataṃ anabhisametaṃ.
an9.13:21.6.eng: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’ …

an9.13:21.7.pli: Tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya pattiyā sacchikiriyāya abhisamayāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussati.

an9.13:21.8.pli: Idaṃ khvassa, āvuso, aññātaṃ adiṭṭhaṃ appattaṃ asacchikataṃ anabhisametaṃ.
an9.13:21.8.eng: This is the unknown, unseen, unattained, unrealized, and uncomprehended.

an9.13:21.9.pli: Tassa ñāṇāya dassanāya pattiyā sacchikiriyāya abhisamayāya bhagavati brahmacariyaṃ vussatī”ti.
an9.13:21.9.eng: The spiritual life is lived under the Buddha to know, see, attain, realize, and comprehend this.”

an9.14:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā samiddhi yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ samiddhiṃ āyasmā sāriputto etadavoca:
an9.14:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Samiddhi went up to Venerable Sāriputta, bowed, and sat to one side. Venerable Sāriputta said to him:

an9.14:2.1.eng: “Samiddhi, based on what do thoughts arise in a person?”

an9.14:11.1.pli: “‘Kimārammaṇā, samiddhi, purisassa saṅkappavitakkā uppajjantī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘nāmarūpārammaṇā, bhante’ti vadesi.
an9.14:11.1.eng: “Samiddhi, when you were asked what is the basis on which thoughts arise in a person, you answered ‘name and form’.

an9.14:11.2.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kva nānattaṃ gacchantī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘dhātūsu, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.3.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃsamudayā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘phassasamudayā, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.4.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃsamosaraṇā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘vedanāsamosaraṇā, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.5.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃpamukhā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘samādhippamukhā, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.6.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃadhipateyyā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘satādhipateyyā, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.7.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃuttarā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘paññuttarā, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.8.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃsārā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘vimuttisārā, bhante’ti vadesi.

an9.14:11.9.pli: ‘Te pana, samiddhi, kiṃogadhā’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘amatogadhā, bhante’ti vadesi.
an9.14:11.9.eng: what is their objective, you answered ‘freedom from death’.

an9.14:11.11.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, samiddhi, puṭṭho puṭṭho vissajjesi, tena ca mā maññī”ti.
an9.14:11.11.eng: It’s good that you answered each question. But don’t get conceited because of that.”

an9.15:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, suppose there was a boil that was many years old.

an9.15:1.2.pli: Tassassu gaṇḍassa nava vaṇamukhāni nava abhedanamukhāni.
an9.15:1.2.eng: And that boil had nine orifices that were continually open wounds.

an9.15:1.4.pli: asuciyeva pagghareyya, duggandhaṃyeva pagghareyya, jegucchiyaṃyeva pagghareyya;
an9.15:1.4.eng: would be filthy, stinking, and disgusting.

an9.15:1.6.pli: asuciyeva pasaveyya, duggandhaṃyeva pasaveyya, jegucchiyaṃyeva pasaveyya.
an9.15:1.6.eng: would be filthy, stinking, and disgusting.

an9.15:2.1.pli: Gaṇḍoti kho, bhikkhave, imassetaṃ cātumahābhūtikassa kāyassa adhivacanaṃ mātāpettikasambhavassa odanakummāsūpacayassa aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṃsanadhammassa.
an9.15:2.1.eng: ‘Boil’ is a term for this body made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.

an9.15:2.2.pli: Tassassu gaṇḍassa nava vaṇamukhāni nava abhedanamukhāni.
an9.15:2.2.eng: And that boil has nine orifices that are continually open wounds.

an9.15:2.4.pli: asuciyeva paggharati, duggandhaṃyeva paggharati, jegucchiyaṃyeva paggharati;

an9.15:2.6.pli: asuciyeva pasavati, duggandhaṃyeva pasavati, jegucchiyaṃyeva pasavati.

an9.15:2.7.eng: So, mendicants, have no illusion about this body.”

an9.16:1.1.pli: “Navayimā, bhikkhave, saññā bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā.
an9.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these nine perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. Their objective and culmination is freedom from death.

an9.16:1.3.pli: Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā—
an9.16:1.3.eng: The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, not-self in suffering, giving up, and fading away.

an9.16:1.4.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, nava saññā, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā honti mahānisaṃsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā”ti.
an9.16:1.4.eng: These nine perceptions, when developed and cultivated, are very fruitful and beneficial. Their objective and culmination is freedom from death.”

an9.17:1.1.pli: “Navahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgataṃ kulaṃ anupagantvā vā nālaṃ upagantuṃ, upagantvā vā nālaṃ nisīdituṃ.
an9.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, visiting a family with nine factors is not worthwhile, or if you’ve already arrived, sitting down is not worthwhile.

an9.17:1.3.pli: Na manāpena paccuṭṭhenti, na manāpena abhivādenti, na manāpena āsanaṃ denti, santamassa pariguhanti, bahukampi thokaṃ denti, paṇītampi lūkhaṃ denti, asakkaccaṃ denti no sakkaccaṃ, na upanisīdanti dhammassavanāya, bhāsitamassa na sussūsanti.
an9.17:1.3.eng: They don’t politely rise, bow, or offer a seat. They hide what they have. Even when they have much they give little. Even when they have fine things they give coarse things. They give carelessly, not carefully. They don’t sit nearby to listen to the teachings. When you’re speaking, they don’t listen well.

an9.17:1.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, navahaṅgehi samannāgataṃ kulaṃ anupagantvā vā nālaṃ upagantuṃ upagantvā vā nālaṃ nisīdituṃ.
an9.17:1.4.eng: Visiting a family with these nine factors is not worthwhile, or if you’ve already arrived, sitting down is not worthwhile.

an9.17:2.1.pli: Navahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgataṃ kulaṃ anupagantvā vā alaṃ upagantuṃ, upagantvā vā alaṃ nisīdituṃ.
an9.17:2.1.eng: Visiting a family with nine factors is worthwhile, or if you’ve already arrived, sitting down is worthwhile.

an9.17:2.3.pli: Manāpena paccuṭṭhenti, manāpena abhivādenti, manāpena āsanaṃ denti, santamassa na pariguhanti, bahukampi bahukaṃ denti, paṇītampi paṇītaṃ denti, sakkaccaṃ denti no asakkaccaṃ, upanisīdanti dhammassavanāya, bhāsitamassa sussūsanti.
an9.17:2.3.eng: They politely rise, bow, and offer a seat. They don’t hide what they have. When they have much they give much. When they have refined things they give refined things. They give carefully, not carelessly. They sit nearby to listen to the teachings. When you’re speaking, they listen well.

an9.17:2.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, navahaṅgehi samannāgataṃ kulaṃ anupagantvā vā alaṃ upagantuṃ, upagantvā vā alaṃ nisīditun”ti.
an9.17:2.4.eng: Visiting a family with these nine factors is worthwhile, or if you’ve already arrived, sitting down is worthwhile.”

an9.18:1.1.pli: “Navahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato uposatho upavuttho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
an9.18:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the observance of the sabbath with its nine factors is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.

an9.18:1.2.pli: Kathaṃ upavuttho ca, bhikkhave, navahaṅgehi samannāgato uposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro?
an9.18:1.2.eng: And how should it be observed?

an9.18:1.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:

an9.18:1.4.pli: ‘yāvajīvaṃ arahanto pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā nihitadaṇḍā nihitasatthā lajjī dayāpannā sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampino viharanti;
an9.18:1.4.eng: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They are scrupulous and kind, and live full of sympathy for all living beings.

an9.18:1.5.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharāmi.
an9.18:1.5.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I’ll be scrupulous and kind, and live full of sympathy for all living beings.

an9.18:1.6.pli: Imināpaṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi; uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
an9.18:1.6.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’

an9.18:2.1.pli: ‘Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭiviratā nīcaseyyaṃ kappenti—mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā;
an9.18:2.1.eng: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up high and luxurious beds. They sleep in a low place, either a cot or a straw mat.

an9.18:2.2.pli: ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato nīcaseyyaṃ kappemi—mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā.
an9.18:2.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up high and luxurious beds. I’ll sleep in a low place, either a cot or a straw mat.

an9.18:2.3.pli: Imināpaṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi; uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
an9.18:2.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’

an9.18:3.1.pli: Mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṃ disaṃ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṃ tathā tatiyaṃ tathā catutthaṃ. Iti uddhamadho tiriyaṃ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṃ lokaṃ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
an9.18:3.1.eng: They meditate spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

an9.18:4.1.pli: Evaṃ upavuttho kho, bhikkhave, navahaṅgehi samannāgato uposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro”ti.
an9.18:4.1.eng: The observance of the sabbath with its nine factors in this way is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.”

an9.19:1.1.pli: “Imañca, bhikkhave, rattiṃ sambahulā devatā abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇā kevalakappaṃ jetavanaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhikkhave, tā devatā maṃ etadavocuṃ:
an9.19:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, tonight, several glorious deities, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, came to me, bowed, stood to one side, and said to me:

an9.19:1.2.pli: ‘upasaṅkamiṃsu no, bhante, pubbe manussabhūtānaṃ pabbajitā agārāni.
an9.19:1.2.eng: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.

an9.19:1.3.pli: Te mayaṃ, bhante, paccuṭṭhimha, no ca kho abhivādimha.
an9.19:1.3.eng: We politely rose for them, but we didn’t bow.

an9.19:1.4.pli: Tā mayaṃ, bhante, aparipuṇṇakammantā vippaṭisāriniyo paccānutāpiniyo hīnaṃ kāyaṃ upapannā’ti.
an9.19:1.4.eng: And so, having not fulfilled our duty, full of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a lesser realm.’

an9.19:2.1.pli: Aparāpi maṃ, bhikkhave, sambahulā devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
an9.19:2.1.eng: Then several other deities came to me and said:

an9.19:2.2.pli: ‘upasaṅkamiṃsu no, bhante, pubbe manussabhūtānaṃ pabbajitā agārāni.
an9.19:2.2.eng: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.

an9.19:2.3.pli: Te mayaṃ, bhante, paccuṭṭhimha abhivādimha, no ca tesaṃ āsanaṃ adamha.
an9.19:2.3.eng: We politely rose for them and bowed, but we didn’t offer a seat.

an9.19:2.4.pli: Tā mayaṃ, bhante, aparipuṇṇakammantā vippaṭisāriniyo paccānutāpiniyo hīnaṃ kāyaṃ upapannā’ti.
an9.19:2.4.eng: And so, having not fulfilled our duty, full of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a lesser realm.’

an9.19:3.1.pli: Aparāpi maṃ, bhikkhave, sambahulā devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
an9.19:3.1.eng: Then several other deities came to me and said:

an9.19:3.2.pli: ‘upasaṅkamiṃsu no, bhante, pubbe manussabhūtānaṃ pabbajitā agārāni.
an9.19:3.2.eng: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.

an9.19:3.3.pli: Te mayaṃ, bhante, paccuṭṭhimha abhivādimha āsanaṃ adamha, no ca kho yathāsatti yathābalaṃ saṃvibhajimha …pe…
an9.19:3.3.eng: We politely rose for them, bowed, and offered a seat, but we didn’t share as best we could. …’

an9.19:3.4.pli: yathāsatti yathābalaṃ saṃvibhajimha, no ca kho upanisīdimha dhammassavanāya …pe…
an9.19:3.4.eng: ‘… we didn’t sit nearby to listen to the teachings. …’

an9.19:3.5.pli: upanisīdimha dhammassavanāya, no ca kho ohitasotā dhammaṃ suṇimha …pe…
an9.19:3.5.eng: ‘… we didn’t actively listen to the teachings. …’

an9.19:3.6.pli: ohitasotā ca dhammaṃ suṇimha, no ca kho sutvā dhammaṃ dhārayimha …pe…

an9.19:3.7.pli: sutvā ca dhammaṃ dhārayimha, no ca kho dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhimha …pe…
an9.19:3.7.eng: ‘… we didn’t examine the meaning of teachings we’d memorized. …’

an9.19:3.8.pli: dhātānañca dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhimha, no ca kho atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammaṃ paṭipajjimha.
an9.19:3.8.eng: ‘… not having understood the meaning and the teaching, we didn’t practice in line with the teaching.

an9.19:3.9.pli: Tā mayaṃ, bhante, aparipuṇṇakammantā vippaṭisāriniyo paccānutāpiniyo hīnaṃ kāyaṃ upapannā’ti.
an9.19:3.9.eng: And so, having not fulfilled our duty, full of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a lesser realm.’

an9.19:4.1.pli: Aparāpi maṃ, bhikkhave, sambahulā devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
an9.19:4.1.eng: Then several other deities came to me and said:

an9.19:4.2.pli: ‘upasaṅkamiṃsu no, bhante, pubbe manussabhūtānaṃ pabbajitā agārāni.
an9.19:4.2.eng: ‘Sir, formerly when we were human beings, renunciates came to our homes.

an9.19:4.3.pli: Te mayaṃ, bhante, paccuṭṭhimha abhivādimha, āsanaṃ adamha, yathāsatti yathābalaṃ saṃvibhajimha, upanisīdimha dhammassavanāya, ohitasotā ca dhammaṃ suṇimha, sutvā ca dhammaṃ dhārayimha, dhātānañca dhammānaṃ atthaṃ upaparikkhimha, atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammaṃ paṭipajjimha.
an9.19:4.3.eng: We politely rose, bowed, and offered them a seat. We shared as best we could. We sat nearby to listen to the teachings, lent an ear, memorized them, and examined their meaning. Understanding the teaching and the meaning we practiced in line with the teaching.

an9.19:4.4.pli: Tā mayaṃ, bhante, paripuṇṇakammantā avippaṭisāriniyo apaccānutāpiniyo paṇītaṃ kāyaṃ upapannā’ti.
an9.19:4.4.eng: And so, having fulfilled our duty, free of remorse and regret, we were reborn in a superior realm.’

an9.19:4.5.pli: Etāni, bhikkhave, rukkhamūlāni etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyatha, bhikkhave, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha seyyathāpi tā purimikā devatā”ti.
an9.19:4.5.eng: Here, mendicants, are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later, like those former deities.”

an9.2:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an9.2:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an9.2:1.3.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bhikkhu nissayasampanno hotī”ti?
an9.2:1.3.eng: How is a mendicant who is supported defined?”

an9.2:1.4.pli: “Saddhañce, bhikkhu, bhikkhu nissāya akusalaṃ pajahati kusalaṃ bhāveti, pahīnamevassa taṃ akusalaṃ hoti.
an9.2:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, if a mendicant supported by faith gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful, the unskillful is actually given up by them.

an9.2:1.5.eng: If a mendicant supported by conscience …

an9.2:1.6.eng: If a mendicant supported by prudence …

an9.2:1.7.eng: If a mendicant supported by energy …

an9.2:1.8.pli: paññañce, bhikkhu, bhikkhu nissāya akusalaṃ pajahati kusalaṃ bhāveti, pahīnamevassa taṃ akusalaṃ hoti.
an9.2:1.8.eng: If a mendicant supported by wisdom gives up the unskillful and develops the skillful, the unskillful is actually given up by them.

an9.2:1.9.pli: Taṃ hissa bhikkhuno akusalaṃ pahīnaṃ hoti suppahīnaṃ, yaṃsa ariyāya paññāya disvā pahīnaṃ.
an9.2:1.9.eng: What’s been given up is completely given up when it has been given up by seeing with noble wisdom.

an9.2:2.1.pli: Tena ca pana, bhikkhu, bhikkhunā imesu pañcasu dhammesu patiṭṭhāya cattāro upanissāya vihātabbā.
an9.2:2.1.eng: But then, a mendicant grounded on these five things should rely on four things.

an9.2:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhu, bhikkhu saṅkhāyekaṃ paṭisevati, saṅkhāyekaṃ adhivāseti, saṅkhāyekaṃ parivajjeti, saṅkhāyekaṃ vinodeti.
an9.2:2.3.eng: After appraisal, a mendicant uses some things, endures some things, avoids some things, and gets rid of some things.

an9.2:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, bhikkhu nissayasampanno hotī”ti.
an9.2:2.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant is supported.”
